review.title: “Stagnant”
review.pros: Pros – Work life balance ranges from good to excellent overall. There are opportunities to grow on the technical side particularly if you work directly with TSI's partners VMware and/or NetApp
review.cons: Cons – Management practices penny pinching at a level that doesn't make sense, capex approvals get stalled even though orders are confirmed and customers are waiting.There's also very silo, non-global/non-enterprise thinking where different country business units compete with each other to get business at the expense of the employees and the end customer.Management also doesn't seem to get that technology moves forward at such a fast rate and the company needs to invest to grow and be more profitable. See my first point.For an IT company, TSI is so far backwards that I can only shake my head. Approvals are still done manually ie. print, sign, scan, email. This hasn't improved in the 2+ years I've been in the company!
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Be more global, thinking, culturally and process wise. Look at the big picture, not at what the spreadsheet says today.

review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Making money is a great byproduct of a great product, it should not be your main aim. Stop with those constant reorganizations

review.title: “An average company for an mediocre employee to work for”
review.pros: Pros – The company provides lot's of opportunity for the employees and have the intention and effort in rebranding the company for a presence as Point of Production. On paper, this is a promising company to work for. There's also positive intention to groom university leavers and enroll them into ICT Academy. As a results, young people began to know the company slowly.
review.cons: Cons – Bureaucracy, internal politics, no proper process, lack of staff concrete development plan and "mediocre" leadership capability unfortunately have been impacting the overall company. In addition, the pay structure is not as compelling to other tech companies surrounding the area.On the other hand, huge culture gap between German headquarters and existing staff in Malaysia with mixed dutch folks felt the intense of having effective communication. The reason behind is prior the establishment of the company, a huge transition from ex-Shell IT staffs are being "acquired". These talents pool are very deep in their knowledge and experiences as a result of previous organization development structure and cultural bonding.As a result, these people came from true global company to a yet-to-be global practice company. Hence, it is hard for these capable folks to understand how they can be part of the company culture. In the end, they leave and today there are very few left over in the company. They maybe waiting to leave. However, even young newer joiners and some from Academy also have that intention too.Most of the establishing cultural with Guiding Principles are only good on paper but not in reality. Branding should be a good exercise, unfortunately the strategy of branding may seem a little exaggerating as the original company does not involved in retail. On superficial level, the branding works to tell public about us, but in reality there are very little effort of employees promoting the company as a place to work for.There are lot's of information that being cascaded down in a non-transparent manner and it is via LT in a silent mode and of course when the news delivered it is almost like breaking news. On second thought, all of us work like guerrilla mode. With that, many of the work, decision and new are either being implemented as in NOW or will never get implemented on time.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – T-Systems International Leadership may know what to do most of the time. Therefore more advice would be unnecessary. It is more like turning the common sense into common practice. Building world class company takes time, but importantly world class company comes from well-developed employees and leaders need to prepare to relearn and listen what can be improved quickly.

review.title: “T-Systems Malaysia is really a young company with lot of shell vicious. It has to grow in maturity.”
review.pros: Pros – It is one of the leading outsources. A good choice to have in your CV. They are dealing with all Shell internal IT.
review.cons: Cons – It's really an immature company with too much politics. They can kill even themselves. The dependency from Germany makes sometimes difficult to evolve in a way the company needs. Most of the times the German mentality don't understand at all this part of Asia and tries to repeat several times the same, as if it was not correctly understood.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Clean up the company. It's still possible. Put some more westerner management or local people that has been educated abroad as an interface with Germany.

review.title: “its good”

review.cons: Cons – The salary is not on par with market level
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Dont be afraid to hire expert rather than paying penalties

review.title: “learnt alot, pity the cost driven culture stunts the pay”
review.pros: Pros – Opportunity to work with some of the most up to date versions of Database software.At least one course a year.UK base has a very well structured, and mature, change and incident management process.flexibilty to work from home and management trust their employees to get on with it, which is refreshing in this market.
review.cons: Cons – Compensation. Contractors who came across as permanent staff from T-Mobile were paid 3 times what other permanents staff were. Even a promotion failed to improve my salary by more than £1000.Senior management referring to IT staff as factory workers does not have any positive reflections, and makes us think we are working in a sweat shop.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – IT technicians are not factory workers... if we were, we would come to work in overalls.

review.title: “Lots of growth opportunities limited by uninspired management and German-centric culture.”
review.pros: Pros – There is good work-life balance and good benefits for employees. The location in Malaysia (Cyberjaya) is also reasonable with minimal traffic going to/from work.
review.cons: Cons – Inept management, terrible communications between management and employees. Every senior VP wants to be involved in any operations escalation and operations teams seem to be blamed for every little problem that occurs that's outside of their control. We also get the feeling that no major decisions are made outside of Germany.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Know the company's strategic direction and stick to it. Micro managing does not help the technical team do their work.

review.title: “Bad management”
review.pros: Pros – Felxible working hoursMedical benefits are good
review.cons: Cons – No travellingToo much into cost cuttingNo trainingManagement are not good in making decision
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Need to restructure the management group

review.title: “Everything's an escalation, there's even such a thing as "Advance Escalation"!”
review.pros: Pros – Because of the global outsourcing deal from Shell IT services to T-Systems, most Shell ex-employees have their benefits with them (and they're good). Salary is not excellent, but competitive enough. Strong branding efforts to promote the company in Malaysia as a Global Delivery Hub.
review.cons: Cons – Management by escalation, constant fire fighting, weak processes affect overall service delivery quality. Management playing musical chairs, restructuring and changing ideologies all the time. No close communication between Germany and the rest of the world, always a border drawn around Germany processes and tools. Overall, the company is not a true globalized company, and it frustrates its employees.I've seen a freeze to everything from hiring, to training and travel freeze.Management objective is to maintain (or reduce) headcount, but increase quality, which is idealistic because there is no strong structure around the individual (silo) organizations around the world. LOADS of politicking and bureaucracies to go around
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Invest in best talents in all levels instead of paying penalties to customers for not delivering. Observe the guiding principles that you want the employees to follow (lead by example), get more focused control over the services delivery management organization (right now, it's "overcommit --> under deliver"), have stronger billing/charging structure to recover costs.

review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Unfortunately, I do not think that leadership at T-Systems would even bother looking at this feedback, let alone accept this as honest input.
